qas.question: What was the headline for a page 2 Sun story on 17 November 1989?

answers.text: "STRAIGHT SEX CANNOT GIVE YOU AIDS – OFFICIAL."

qas.question: Whose opinion did The Sun trust in their AIDS reporting?
Which groups were classified as being at a high risk for AIDS?
With which group was Lord Kilbracken associated?
How did other news outlets report on Lord Kilbracken's words?

answers.text: none of them presented Lord Kilbracken's ideas without context or criticism

context: On 17 November 1989, The Sun headlined a page 2 news story titled <a0_0>"STRAIGHT SEX CANNOT GIVE YOU AIDS – OFFICIAL."<a0_0/> The Sun favourably cited the opinions of <a1_0>Lord Kilbracken<a1_0/>, a member of the <a3_0>All Parliamentary Group on AIDS<a3_0/>. Lord Kilbracken said that only one person out of the 2,372 individuals with HIV/AIDS mentioned in a specific Department of Health report was not a member of a "high risk group", such as <a2_0>homosexuals and recreational drug users<a2_0/>. The Sun also ran an editorial further arguing that "At last the truth can be told... the risk of catching AIDS if you are heterosexual is "statistically invisible". In other words, impossible. So now we know – everything else is homosexual propaganda." Although many other British press services covered Lord Kilbracken's public comments, none of them made the argument that the Sun did in its editorial and <a4_0>none of them presented Lord Kilbracken's ideas without context or criticism<a4_0/>.
